function_call.name: write_files

message.content:
The generated code uses a mutable list as a default argument in the File class. This is a common Python pitfall. Instead of using a mutable default argument, a better practice is to use a default argument of None and then set the actual default value inside the method if the argument is None. This ensures that each instance of the class gets its own copy of the default value, not a shared copy. This can be done by changing the File class definition to:

```python
@dataclass
class File:
    name: str
    size: int
    owner: str
    versions: list = None

    def __init__(self, name, size, owner, versions=None):
        self.name = name
        self.size = size
        self.owner = owner
        self.versions = versions if versions is not None else []
```

This change will prevent potential bugs related to mutable default arguments.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The current implementation of the application uses in-memory storage for users and files. This means that all data will be lost once the application is restarted. To improve this, a persistent storage solution such as a database could be used. This would involve modifying the application to interact with the database for storing and retrieving users and files. This would make the application more robust and suitable for real-world usage.
